name: Medieval Manchester — Borough Charter Era (c.1300)
description: Manchester around the time of its 1301 borough charter. The market town with its church, manor house, market cross, and first defined streets. Scholarly reconstructions show the medieval core.
notes:
RESEARCH TARGET: Find reconstruction maps of medieval Manchester.

1282: Grelly family sell the manor.
1301: Borough charter granted — market rights, right to elect reeve.
1311: De la Warre family inherit.
1322: Scottish raids into Lancashire.
1348-49: Black Death.

Medieval core centred on:
- Church of St Mary (now Cathedral)
- Market place (now Exchange Square area)
- Hanging Ditch (defensive ditch)
- Millgate, Deansgate, Market Street
- Manor house / baron's hall

Possible sources:
- 'Medieval Manchester' by John Harland
- 'Manchester: Making the Modern City' (Manchester University Press)
- Chetham Society publications (19th century antiquarian studies)
- GMAU excavation reports from Cathedral/Exchange Square area
- 'The Growth of Manchester' reconstruction drawings
- Victoria County History of Lancashire

Hanging Ditch is key — a defensive ditch that defined the medieval town boundary.
Its course is preserved in modern street names.
